question: Hi, I've got an appointment with Mr. Ullman. My name is Jack Torrance. Thank you. Mr. Ullman?
answer: Yes?

question: I'm Jack Torrance.
answer: Oh, well - come on in Jack. Very nice to meet you.

question: Nice to meet you, Mr. Ullman.
answer: This is my secretary, Susie.

question: Susie, how do you do?
answer: Have any trouble finding us?

question: Oh, no problem at all. I made the trip in three and a half hours.
answer: Well, that's very good time, very good. Please sit down a minute. JAck, just make yourself at home. Would you like some coffee?

question: Well, if you are going to have some, I wouldn't mind. Thanks.
answer: Susie. Oh, and would you ask Bill Watson to join us?

question: Mom...
answer: Yeah.

question: Do you really want to go and live in that hotel for the winter?
answer: Sure, Danny, it will be lots of fun.

question: Yeah, I guess so. Anyway, there's hardly anybody to play with around here.
answer: Yeah, I know. It always takes a little time to make new friends.

question: Yeah, I guess so.
answer: What about Tony? He's looking forward to the hotel, I bet.

question: What about Tony? He's looking forward to the hotel, I bet.
answer: NO, I ain't Mrs. Torrance.

question: Oh come on, Tony. Don't be silly.
answer: I don't want to go there, Mrs. Torrance.

question: Well, how come you don't want to go?
answer: I just don't.

question: Eh - formerly a school-teacher.
answer: What line of work are you in now?

question: I'm a writer um... Teaching has been more or less a way of making ends meet.
answer: Well this ought to be quite a change for you.

question: Well, I'm looking for a change.
answer: Our people in Denver recommended Jack very highly, and, for once, I agree with them. Let's see, where were we? Yes. I was about to explain that eh... our season here runs from oh May 15th to October 30th and then we close down completely until the following May.

question: Do you mind if I ask why you do that? It seems to me that the skiing up here would be fantastic.
answer: Oh, it sure would be but the problem is the enormous cost it would be to keep the road to the Sidewinder open. It's a... It's a 25 mile stretch of road - gets an average of 20 feet of snow during the winter, and there's just no way to make it economically feasible to keep it clear. When the place was built in 1907, there was very little interest in winter sports, and this site was chosen for its seclusion and scenic beauty.

question: Well, it's certainly got plenty of that.
answer: That's right. And did they give you any idea in Denver about what the job entails?

question: Only in a very general way.
answer: Well... ...the winters can be fantastically cruel, and the basic idea is to...to cope with the very costly damage and depreciation which can occur. And this consists mainly of running the boiler, heating different parts of the hotel on a daily rotating basis, repairing damage as it occurs and doing repairs, so that the elements can't get a foothold.

question: Well, that sounds fine to me.
answer: Physically, it's not a very demanding job. The only thing that can get a bit trying up here during the winter is eh... the tremendous sense of isolation.

question: Well, that just happens to be exactly what I'm looking for. I'm eh... I'm outlining a new writing project, and eh... five months of peace is just what I want.
answer: That's very good Jack, because eh... for some people eh solitude and isolation... can of itself be a problem.

question: Not for me.
answer: How about your wife and son? How do you think they'll take to it?

question: They'll love it.
answer: Great... Well, before I turn you over to Bill, there is one other thing I think we should talk about. I don't want to sound melodramatic, but it is something that's... been known to give a few people second thoughts about the job.

question: I'm intrigued.
answer: I don't suppose they eh told you anything in Denver about the tragedy we had up here during the winter of 1970?

question: I don't believe they did.
answer: Well, my predecessor in this job hired a man named Charles Grady, as the winter caretaker. He came up here with his wife and two little girls of about eight or ten. And he had a good employment record, good references and from what I've been told, I mean, he seemed like a completely normal individual. But at some point during the winter, he must have suffered some kind of a complete mental breakdown. He ran amok and eh... killed his family with an axe, stacked them neatly in one of the rooms in the West Wing, and then he um... then he put eh both barrels of his shotgun in his mouth. The police eh... they thought that it was what the old-timers used to call cabin-fever, a kind of claustrophobic reaction which can occur when people are shut in together over long periods of time.

question: Well, that is eh quite a story.
answer: Yes, it is. Oh, it's still hard for me to believe that it actually happened here, but it did and eh... I think you can appreciate why I wanted to tell you about it.

question: Ah, I certainly can, and eh... I also understand why your people in Denver left it for you to tell me.
answer: Well, obviously some people can be put off by the idea of staying alone in a place where something like that actually happened.

question: Hello.
answer: Hi, babe.

question: Hi, hon. How's it going?
answer: Great. Look, I'm at the hotel and I still have an awful lot to go through. I don't think I can get home before nine or ten.

question: Sounds like you got the job?
answer: Right it's a beautiful place. You and Danny are gonna love it.

question: Tony, why don't you want to go to the hotel?
answer: I don't know.

question: You do too know, now come on tell me.
answer: I don't want to.

question: Please...
answer: No.

question: Now Tony, tell me.
answer: Now hold your eyes still so that I can see. That's good, now the other one. Good boy. Now Danny, when you were brushing your teeth, do you remember if you smelled anything funny, or saw any bright flashing lights, or anything at all strange?

question: No.
answer: Do you remember when you were brushing your teeth?

question: Yes.
answer: What's the next thing you remember after you were brushing your teeth?

question: Mommy saying, 'Wake up, wake up, wake up Danny, wake up.'
answer: Now Danny, can you remember what you were doing just before you started brushing your teeth?

question: Talking to Tony.
answer: Is Tony one of your animals?

question: Oh, if you were to open your mouth now, could I see Tony?
answer: No.

question: Why not?
answer: Because he hides.

question: Where does he go?
answer: To my stomach.

question: Does Tony ever tell you to do things?
answer: I don't want to talk about Tony anymore.

question: Okay. That's fine. All right Danny. Now I'm going to ask you to do me a favor, and stay quietly in bed for the rest of the day. Okay?
answer: Do I have to?

question: Goodbye.
answer: Shall we go into the living room?

question: Yes.
answer: Please...

question: Thank you. Mrs. Torrance, I don't think you have anything to worry about. I'm quite sure there is nothing physically wrong with Danny.
answer: Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah, he seems absolutely fine now, but you should have seen him.

question: Oh I know. Kids can scare you to death, but believe me these episodes are not at all uncommon, and they look much worse than they are.
answer: But eh what was the matter with him?

question: Mrs. Torrance, most of the time these episodes with kids are never explained. They are brought on by emotional factors, and they rarely occur again. They're more akin to auto-hypnosis, a kind of self induced trance. If it re-occurs which I doubt you can always think about having some tests done. No thank you.
answer: Oh, I'm...I'm sure you're right.

question: Have you been in Boulder long, Mrs. Torrance?
answer: Only about three months. Eh we're from Vermont. My husband was teaching school there.

question: Did the appearance of Danny's imaginary friend...?
answer: Tony.

question: Did Tony's first appearance happen to coincide with your arrival here?
answer: No, um let's see I guess Danny started talkin to Tony about the time we put him into nursery school.

question: Did he adjust well to school?
answer: No. He didn't like it too much at first, and then he had an injury, so we kept him out for a while, and, yeah, I...I guess that's about the time when I first noticed that he was talking to Tony.

question: What sort of injury did he have?
answer: Ah he dislocated his shoulder.

question: How did he manage to do that?
answer: Well it's just one of those things. You know... purely an accident, um. My husband had oh... been drinking, and he came home about three hours late, so he wasn't exactly in the greatest mood that night. And well Danny had scattered some of his school papers all over the room... and my husband grabbed his arm, you know, and pulled him away from them. It's...it's just the sort of thing you do a hundred times with a child - you know, in a park or on the streets - but on this particular occasion my husband just... used too much strength and he injured Danny's arm. Anyway, something good did come out of it all because he said: "Wendy, I'm never gonna touch another drop and if I do you can leave me", and he didn't and he hasn't had any alcohol in eh five months. Boy, we must be really high up. The air feels so different.

question: Uh...huh.
answer: Dad?

question: Yes?
answer: I'm hungry.

question: I think that was farther west in the Sierras.
answer: What was the Donner party?

question: There were a party of settlers in the covered wagon times. They got snowbound one winter in the mountains. They had to resort to cannabilism in order to stay alive.
answer: You mean they ate each other up?

question: Well, that still gives up plenty of time to go over everything first. Goodbye. Good morning Jack. I hope you haven't been waiting too long.
answer: No problem. In fact we had time to grab a bite to eat.

question: Good. Glad you made it before they shut down the kitchen. Is your family having a look around?
answer: No, my son's discovered the games room.

question: Oh... Has your luggage been brought in?
answer: Right there.

question: God, I've never seen anything like this before. Are all of these Indian designs authentic?
answer: Yes, I believe they are based mainly on Navajo and Apache motifs.

question: Oh well they're really gorgeous. As a matter of fact this is probably the most gorgeous hotel I've ever seen.
answer: Oh this old place has had an illustrious past. In its heyday it was one of the stopping places for the jet set, even before anybody knew what a jet set was. We've had four presidents who stayed here, lots of movie stars.

question: Royalty?
answer: All the best people. This is the staff wing of the hotel. None of the other bedrooms are heated during the winter.

question: Oh!
answer: Goodbye girls. And here are your quarters. Living Room, bedroom, bathroom, and a small bedroom for your son.

question: Yeah.
answer: This is our famous hedge maze. It's quite an attraction around here. The walls are thirteen feet high and the hedges are about as old as the hotel itself. It's a lot of fun, but I wouldn't go in there unless I had an hour to spare to find my way out.

question: When was the Overlook built?
answer: Ah... construction started in 1907. It was finished in 1909. The site is supposed to be located on an Indian burial ground, and I believe they actually had to repel a few Indian attacks as they were building it. That's our Snowcat. Can you both drive a car? That's fine because basically the Snowcat operates very much like a car and it won't take you long to get the hang of it. As a matter of fact we eh... brought a decorator in from Chicago just last year to refurbish this part of the hotel.

question: Oh well he sure did a beautiful job. Pink and gold are my favorite colors.
answer: Oh...well this is our gold ballroom.

question: Oh, I'll say.
answer: We can accommodate up to three hundred people here very comfortably.

question: Boy, I bet you we could really have a good party in this room, huh hon?
answer: I'm afraid you're not going to do too well here unless you've brought your own supplies. We always remove all the booze from the premises when we shut down: that reduces the insurance that we normally have to carry.

question: Mrs. Torrance, your husband introduced you as Winifred. Now are you a Winnie or a Freddie?
answer: I'm a Wendy.

question: Oh Wendy. That's nice. That's the prettiest.
answer: God. This is the kitchen, huh?

question: Well one thing for sure, you don't have to worry about food because you folks could eat up here a whole year and never have the same menu twice. Now right here is our walk-in freezer. Now this is where we keep all of out meat. You got fifteen rib roasts - thirty ten pound bags of hamburgers. You got twelve- turkeys, two dozen pork roasts and twenty legs of lamb. Do you like lamb, Doc?
answer: No.

question: You don't? Well what's your favorite food then?
answer: French Fries and Ketchup.

question: Well I think we can manage that too, Doc. Come along now. Watch your step.
answer: Mr. Halloran, how did you know we called him 'Doc'?

question: Beg pardon?
answer: Doc. You called Danny 'Doc' twice just now.

question: I did?
answer: Yeah. We call him Doc sometimes, you know, like in the Bugs Bunny cartoons. But how did you know that?

question: Well I guess I probably heard you call him that.
answer: Well, it's possible, but I honestly don't remember calling him that since we've been with you.

question: How long have you been able to do it? Why don't you want to talk about it?
answer: I'm not supposed to.

question: Who says you ain't supposed to?
answer: Tony.

question: Who's Tony?
answer: Tony's the little boy who lives in my mouth.

question: Is Tony the one that tells you things?
answer: Yes.

question: How does he tell you things?
answer: It's like I go to sleep, and he shows me things but when I wake up, I can't remember everything.

question: Does your Mum and Dad know about Tony?
answer: Yes.

question: Do they know he tell you things? Has Tony ever told you anything about this place? About the Overlook Hotel?
answer: I don't know.

question: Now think real hard, Doc. Think.
answer: Maybe he showed me something.

question: Try to think what it was.
answer: Mr. Halloran, are you scared of this place?

question: No, I'm scared of nothing here. It's just that you know some places are like people, some shine and some don't. I guess you could say the Overlook Hotel here has something about it that's like shining.
answer: Is there something bad here?

question: Well, you know Doc, when something happens it can leave a trace of itself behind... say like is someone burns toast. Well, maybe things that happened... leave other kinds of traces behind. Not things that anyone can notice, but things that people who shine can see. Just like they can see things that haven't happened yet. Well, sometimes they can see things that happened a long time ago... I think a lot of things happened right here in this particular hotel - over the years, and not all of them was good.
answer: What about Room 237?

question: Room 237?
answer: You're scared of Room 237, ain'tcha?

question: No I ain't.
answer: Mr. Halloran, what is in Room 237?

question: Good Morning, hon. Your breakfast is ready.
answer: What time is it?

question: It's about eleven thirty.
answer: Eleven thirty - Jesus!

question: I guess we've been staying up too late.
answer: I know it.

question: I made 'em just the way you like 'em, sunny side up.
answer: Hmm, nice.

question: It's really pretty outside. How about taking me for a walk after you've finished your breakfast?
answer: Oh I suppose I oughta try to do some writing first.

question: Any ideas yet?
answer: Lots of ideas. No good ones.

question: Well, something'll come. It's just a matter of settling back into the habit of writing every day.
answer: Yeah... that's all it is.

question: It's really nice up here, isn't it?
answer: I love it. I really do. I've never been this happy, or comfortable anywhere.

question: Yeah. It's amazing how fast you get used to such a big place. I tell you, when we first came up here, I thought it was kinda scarey.
answer: I fell in love with it right away. When I came up here from my interview, it was as though I had been here before. We...we all have moments of deja vu, but this was ridiculous. It was almost as though I knew what was going to be around every corner. Ooohhhhh...

question: The loser has to keep American clean, how's that?
answer: All right.

question: And you're gonna lose. And I'm gonna get you - you betta run fast! Look out - I'm coming in close. All right?
answer: You'll have to keep America clean.

question: Okay Danny, you win. Let's take the rest of this walking, huh?
answer: Okay...oh!

question: Give me your hand. Oh, isn't it beautiful.
answer: Yeah.

question: Here's a dead end. Oh what a Maze. Isn't it beautiful.
answer: Yeah.

question: It's so pretty.
answer: Yeah.

question: I didn't think it was going to be this big, did you?
answer: No.

question: Hi, hon. How's it going?
answer: Fine.

question: Get a lot written today?
answer: Yes.

question: Hey, the weather forecast said it's going to snow tonight.
answer: What do you want me to do about it?

question: Ah, come on hon. Don't be so grouchy.
answer: I'm not being grouchy. I just want to finish my work.

question: Okay. I understand. I'll come back later on with a couple of sandwiches for you and... maybe you'll let me read something then.
answer: Wendy, let me explain something to you. Whenever you come in here and interrupt me, you're breaking my concentration. you're distracting me, and it will then take me time to get back to where I was, understand?

question: Yes.
answer: Fine. Now we're going to make a new rule. Whenever I am in here and you hear me typing, or whether you don't hear me typing, whatever the fuck you hear me doing in here, when I am in here that means that I am working - that means don't come in. Now do you think you can handle that?

question: Yes.
answer: Fine. Why don't you start right now and get the fuck out of here, hmm?

question: Okay. I know you've got some. Oh no! I knew it! This is KDK 12 calling KDK 1. KDK 12 to KDK 1.
answer: This is KDK 1. We're receiving you. Over.

question: Hi. This is Wendy Torrance at the Overlook Hotel.
answer: Hi. How are you folks getting on up there? Over.

question: Oh we're just fine, but our telephones don't seem to be doing too well. Are the lines down by any chance? Over.
answer: Yes. Quite a few of them are down, due to the storm. Over.

question: Any chance of them being repaired soon? Over.
answer: Well, I wouldn't like to say. Most winters they stay that way until spring. Over.

question: Boy, this storm is really something, isn't it? Over.
answer: Oh yes. It's one of the worst we've had for years. Is there anything else we can do for you, Mrs. Torrance? Over.

question: I suppose not. Over.
answer: Well, if you folks have any problems up there just give us a call, and Mrs. Torrance. I think it might be a good idea if you leave your radio on all the time now. Over.

question: Mom?
answer: Yes?

question: Can I go to my room and get my fire-engine?
answer: Not right now, Daddy's asleep.

question: I won't make any noise.
answer: Come on, Doc. He only went to bed a few hours ago. Can't you wait till later?

question: I won't make a sound, I promise. I'll tip-toe.
answer: Well all right. But really don't make a sound.

question: I won't, Mom.
answer: Make sure you come right back, 'cause I'm going to make lunch soon. Okay?

question: Okay, Mom. Can I go to my room and get my fire-engine?
answer: Come here for a minute, first. How's it going, Doc?

question: Okay.
answer: Are you having a good time?

question: Yes, Dad.
answer: Good. I want you to have a good time.

question: I am, Dad. Dad?
answer: Yes.

question: Do you feel bad?
answer: No. I'm just a little tired.

question: Then why don't you go to sleep?
answer: I can't. I have too much to do.

question: Dad?
answer: Yes?

question: Do you like this hotel?
answer: Yes I do. I love it. Don't you?

question: I guess so.
answer: Good. I want you to like it here. I wish we could stay here for ever, and ever... ever.

question: Dad?
answer: What?

question: You wouldn't ever hurt Mummy and me, would you?
answer: What do you mean? Did your mother ever say that to you - that I would hurt you?

question: No, Dad.
answer: Are you sure?

question: Yes, Dad.
answer: I love you, Danny. I love you more than anything else in the whole world, and I'd never do anything to hurt you, never... You know that, don't you, huh?

question: Yes, Dad.
answer: Good.

question: Jack... Jack... Jack... Jack, honey, what's wrong? What happened, honey? Hon? What's wrong? Jack!
answer: I had... I had the most terrible nightmare I ever had. It's the most horrible dream I ever had.

question: It's okay. It's okay, now. Really.
answer: I dreamed that I... that I killed you and Danny. But I didn't just kill you, I cut you up into little pieces. Oh... My God, I must be losing my mind!

question: Every...everything is just going to be all right. Come on. Here let's get up off the floor. Danny! Everything's okay... Just go play in your room for a while. Your Dad's just got a headache. Danny - mind what I say. Go play in your room! Hon, let me just go and get him out of here. I'll be right back. Danny, why don't you mind me - huh? Danny. Oh my God! Danny what happened to your neck? Danny... what happened to your neck, huh? You did this to him, didn't you? You son of a bitch! You did this to him, didn't you? How could you? How could you?
answer: God, I'd give anything for a drink? My goddam soul, just a glass of beer. Hi Lloyd. A little slow tonight, isn't it?

question: God, I'd give anything for a drink? My goddam soul, just a glass of beer. Hi Lloyd. A little slow tonight, isn't it?
answer: Yes, it is, Mr. Torrance. What'll it be?

question: Now I'm awfully glad you asked me that, Lloyd, because I just happen to have two twenties and two tens right here in my wallet. I was afraid they were going to be there until next April. So here's what
answer: No, sir. I'm not busy at all.

question: Good man. You set them up, and I'll knock them back, Lloyd, one by one. White man's burden, Lloyd my man. White man's burden. Say, Lloyd, it seems I'm temporarily light. How's my credit in this joint anyway?
answer: Your credit's fine, Mr. Torrance.

question: That's swell. I like you, Lloyd. I always liked you. You were always the best of them. Best goddamned bartender from Timbuctoo to Portland Maine - Portland Oregon for that matter.
answer: Thank you for saying so.

question: Here's to five miserable months on the wagon and all the irreparable harm that it's caused me.
answer: How are things going, Mr. Torrance?

question: Things could be better, Lloyd. Things could be a whole lot better.
answer: I hope it's nothing serious.

question: No, nothing serious. Just a little problem with the... old sperm bank upstairs. Nothing that I can't handle though, Lloyd. Thanks.
answer: Women! Can't live with 'em. Can't live without 'em!

question: Words of wisdom, Lloyd. Words of wisdom. I haven't laid a hand on him. Goddam it, I didn't. I wouldn't touch one hair of his goddam little head. I love the little son-of-a- bitch. I'd do anything for him. Any fucking thing for him. That damn bitch. As long as I live she'll never let me forget what happened! I did hurt him once, okay? It was an accident, complete unintentional. It could have happened to anybody. And it was three goddam years ago. The little fucker had thrown all my papers all over the floor. All I tried to do was to pull him up. A momentary loss of muscular coordination. I mean... A few extra foot pounds of energy, per second... per second.
answer: Jack... Oh Jack! Thank God you're here.

question: Are you out of your fucking mind?
answer: No. It's the truth, really. I swear it. Danny told me. He went up into one of the bedrooms, the door was open, and he saw this crazy woman in the bath-tub. She tried to strangle him.

question: Jack?
answer: Yes, it's me.

question: Oh, thank God! Did you find anything?
answer: No, nothing at all. I didn't see one goddam thing.

question: You went into the room Danny said - to 237?
answer: Yes, I did.

question: And you didn't see anything at all?
answer: Absolutely nothing. How is he?

question: He's still asleep.
answer: Good. I'm sure he'll be himself again in the morning.

question: Well, are you sure it was the right room? I mean, maybe Danny made a mistake?
answer: He must have gone into that room - the door was open and the lights were on.

question: Oh, I just don't understand. Well what about those bruises on his neck? Somebody did that to him.
answer: I think he did it to himself.

question: No! No, that's not possible.
answer: Wendy, once you rule out his version of what happened, there is no other explanation - is there? It wouldn't be that different from the episode that he had before we came up here, would it?

question: Jack, whatever the explanation is, I think we have to get Danny out of here.
answer: Get him out of here?

question: Yes.
answer: You mean just leave the hotel?

question: Yes.
answer: It is so fucking typical of you to create a problem like this when I finally have a chance to accomplish something. When I'm really into my work. I could really write my own ticket if I went back to Boulder now, couldn't I? Shovellings out driveways, work in a car wash - any of that appeal to you?

question: Jack...
answer: Wendy, I have let you fuck up my life so far, but I'm not going to let you fuck this up!

question: Good evening. Forest Service.
answer: Hallo. My name's Dick Halloran. I'm the Head Chef up at the Overlook Hotel.

question: Good evening, Mr. Halloran. What can I do for you?
answer: Sir, I've been trying to make an urgent phone call up there, but the operator said that the phone lines are down.

question: Yes, I'm afraid a lot of lines around here are down, due to the storm.
answer: Well, look sir, I hate to put you to any trouble, but there's a family up there all by themselves with a young kid, and with this storm and everything. I'd sure appreciate it if you'd give them a call on your radio just to see if everything is okay.

question: I'd be glad to do that, sir. Oh why don't you call me back in about eh twenty minutes?
answer: Thank you very much. I'll do that.

question: Good evening. Hi Lloyd. I've been away. Now I'm back.
answer: Good evening Mr. Torrance. It's good to see you.

question: It's good to be back, Lloyd.
answer: What'll it be, sir?

question: Hair of the dog that big me.
answer: Bourbon on the rocks.

question: That'll do her.
answer: No charge to you, Mr. Torrance.

question: No charge?
answer: Your money's no good here. Orders from the house.

question: Orders from the house.
answer: Drink up, Mr. Torrance.

question: I'm the kind of man likes to know who's buying their drinks, Lloyd.
answer: It's not a matter that concerns you, Mr. Torrance - at least not at this point.

question: Anything you say, Lloyd. Anything you say.
answer: Oh! Oh dear, oh dear. I'm so sorry, sir. Oh! Oh dear oh dear... I've made an awful mess of your jacket, sir.

question: Oh eh that's all right. I've got plenty of jackets.
answer: I'm afraid it's advocaat sir. It tends to stain.

question: Advocaat is it?
answer: Yes sir. Look um... I think the best thing is to come along to the gentlemen's room, sir, and eh... we'll get some water to it, sir.

question: Looks as though you might have got a spot of it on yourself there, Jeevesy old boy.
answer: That doesn't matter, sir. You're the important one.

question: Awfully nice of you to say. Of course I intend to change my jacket this evening before the fish and goose soiree.
answer: Very wise, sir. Very wise.

question: Here, I'll just, eh... hold this for you there, Jeevesy.
answer: Thank you, sir. Thank you. Now let's see if we can improve this with a little water, sir.

question: Right, I'll just set my bourbon and advocaat down right there.
answer: Won't keep you a moment, sir.

question: Fine. What do they call you around here, Jeevesy?
answer: Grady, sir. Delbert Grady.

question: Grady?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Delbert Grady.
answer: That's right, sir.

question: Eh, Mr. Grady... haven't I seen you somewhere before?
answer: Why no, sir. I don't believe so. Ah ha, it's coming off now, sir.

question: Eh... Mr. Grady... weren't you once the caretaker here?
answer: Why no, sir. I don't believe so.

question: You er a married man, are you, Mr. Grady?
answer: Yes, sir. I have a wife and eh two daughters, sir.

question: And, er... where are they now?
answer: Oh, they're somewhere around. I'm not quite sure at the moment, sir.

question: Mr. Grady, you were the caretaker here. I recognize you. I saw your picture in the newspapers. You eh... chopped your wife and daughters up into little bits, and eh... and you blew your brains out.
answer: That's strange, sir. I don't have any recollection of that at all. Mr. Grady, you were the caretaker here. I'm sorry to differ with you, sir, but you are the caretaker. You have always been the caretaker, I should know, sir. I've always been here. Did you know, Mr. Torrance, that your son... is attempting to bring an outside party into this situation? Did you know that?

question: No.
answer: He is, Mr. Torrance.

question: Who?
answer: A nigger.

question: A nigger!
answer: A nigger cook.

question: How?
answer: Your son has a very great talent. I don't think you are aware how great it is, but he is attempting to use that very talent against your will.

question: Well, he is a very willful boy.
answer: Indeed, he is, Mr. Torrance. A very willful boy. A rather naughty boy, if I may be so bold, sir.

question: It's his mother. She eh... interferes.
answer: Perhaps they need a good talking to, if you don't mind my saying so. Perhaps a bit more. My girls, sir, they didn't care for the Overlook at first. One of them actually stole a packet of matches and tried to burn it down. But I corrected them, sir. And when my wife tried to prevent me from doing my duty I corrected her.

question: We have the Snowcat. If the weather breaks, we might just be able to get down the mountain in that. I could call the Forest Rangers first and then tell them that we're coming so that they could start searching for us, in case we didn't make it. If Jack won't come with us, we'll just have to tell him that we are going by ourselves. That's all there is to it.
answer: Red Rum. Red Rum. Red Rum. Red Rum.

question: Danny?
answer: Red Rum. Red Rum. Red Rum. Red Rum.

question: Danny... what's the matter, hon?
answer: Red Rum.

question: Are you having a bad dream? Danny? Hon?
answer: Danny's not here, Mrs. Torrance.

question: Come on, hon, wake up. You just had a bad dream. Everything's okay.
answer: Danny can't wake up, Mrs. Torrance.

question: Danny, wake up! Come on, right now, Wake up.
answer: Danny's gone away, Mrs. Torrance.

question: Oh, that's very nice of you. I'll call you back later. Bye. Pardon me, miss. What time will we get to Denver? Thank you very much.
answer: Durkin's garage.

question: Hello, can I speak to Larry?
answer: Speaking.

question: Hello Larry. This is Dick, Dick Halloran.
answer: Dick, how are you doing? How's the weather down there?

question: I'm not in Florida, Larry. I'm calling from Stapleton Airport.
answer: What the hell are you doing down there?

question: Well, I just got in from Miami, and I've got to get up to the Overlook today. What's the weather like up there?
answer: Well, the snow ploughs are keeping things moving in town, but the mountain roads are completely blocked.

question: That means I'm going to need a snowcat to get up there, Larry. Can you fix me up with one?
answer: What's the big deal about getting up there today, especially in this kind of weather?

question: Larry, just between you and me, we've got a very serious problem with the people who are taking care of the place. They've turned out to be completely unreliable assholes. Ullman phoned me last night, and I'm supposed to go up there and find out if they have to be replaced.
answer: How long is it going to take you to get up here?

question: Oh about five hours. I'm gonna rent a car here at the airport.
answer: Okay, Dick - I'll take care of it.

question: Oh thanks a lot, Larry. I really appreciate that.
answer: That's all right. Drive carefully.

question: All right. Now I'll be back in just about five minutes. I'm gonna lock the door behind me. Jack...? Jack...?
answer: How do you like it?

question: Jack!
answer: How do you like it? What are you doing down here?

question: I just eh... wanted... ...to talk to you.
answer: Okay. Let's talk. What do you want to talk about?

question: I can't really remember.
answer: You can't remember.

question: No, I can't.
answer: Maybe it was about Danny. Maybe it was about him. I think we should discuss Danny. I think... we should discuss what should be done with him. What should be done with him?

question: I don't know.
answer: I don't think that's true. I think you have some very definite ideas about what should be done with Danny... and I'd like to know what they are.

question: Well I... I think maybe he should be taken to a doctor.
answer: You think maybe he should be taken to a doctor?

question: Yes...
answer: When do you think maybe he should be taken to a doctor?

question: As soon as possible?
answer: As soon as possible.

question: Jack... ...please...
answer: You believe his health might be at stake?

question: Ye...yes.
answer: And you are concerned about him?

question: Yes.
answer: And are you concerned about me?

question: Of course I am.
answer: Of course you are. Have you ever thought about my responsibilities?

question: Oh Jack, what are you talking about?
answer: Have you ever had a single moment's thought about my responsibilities? Have you ever thought for a single solitary moment about my responsibilities to my employers? Has it ever occurred to you that I have agreed to look after the Overlook Hotel until May the first? Does it matter to you at all that the owners have placed their complete confidence and trust in me, and that I have signed a letter of agreement, a contract, in which I have accepted that responsibility? Do you have the slightest idea what a moral and ethical principal is? Do you? Has it ever occurred to you what would happen to my future, if I were to fail to live up to my responsibilities? Has it ever occurred to you? Has it?

question: Stay away from me!
answer: Why?

question: I just want to go back to my room.
answer: Why?

question: Well... I'm very confused, and I just need a chance to think things over.
answer: You've had your whole fucking life to think things over - what's good a few minutes more going to do you now?

question: Jack... stay away from me... please. Don't hurt me! Don't hurt me!
answer: I'm not going to hurt you.

question: Stay away from me,
answer: Wendy!

question: Stay away...!
answer: Darling, light of my life, I'm not going to hurt you. You didn't let me finish my sentence. I said 'I'm not going to hurt you... I'm just going to bash your brains in!' I'm going to bash them right the fuck in.

question: Stay away from me! Stay away from me!
answer: I'm not going to hurt you.

question: Stay away from me! Stay away from me! Please...
answer: Stop swinging the bat.

question: Stay away from me.
answer: Put the bat down, Wendy.

question: Stop it!
answer: Wendy give me the bat.

question: Stay... stay away!
answer: Give me the bat.

question: Stay away from me.
answer: Give me the bat.

question: Jack, stay away from me!
answer: Stop swinging the bat.

question: Get down.
answer: Give me the bat.

question: Go away from me.
answer: Wendy...

question: Go away.
answer: Give me the bat.

question: Go away.
answer: Give me the bat. Goddamn!

question: Oh...oh!
answer: Hey... what are you doing? Ohhh... what are you doing? Hey, wait a minute... What are you doing? What are you doing? Hey, wait a minute! What are you doing? Open the door. Goddamit! Let me out of here! Open the goddam door. Wendy, listen. Let me out of here and I'll forget the whole goddam thing. It'll be just like nothing ever happened. Wendy, baby... I think you hurt my head real bad. I'm dizzy. I need a doctor. Honey... don't leave me in here.

question: I'm gonna go now - I'm going to try and get... get Danny down to the Sidewinder... in the Snowcat today. I'll bring back a doctor.
answer: Wendy...

question: I'm gonna go now.
answer: Wendy...

question: Yes?
answer: You've got a big surprise coming to you. You're not going anywhere. Go check out the Snowcat and the radio and see what I mean. Go check it out! Go check it out! Go check it out! Wendy?

question: You've got a big surprise coming to you. You're not going anywhere. Go check out the Snowcat and the radio and see what I mean. Go check it out! Go check it out! Go check it out! Wendy?
answer: It's Grady, Mr. Torrance. Delbert Grady.

question: Grady... oh. Oh Grady... right. Grady... er... Hullo Grady.
answer: Mr. Torrance, I see you can hardly have taken care of the... business we discussed.

question: No need to rub it in, Mr. Grady. I'll deal with that situation as soon as I get out of here.
answer: Will you indeed, Mr. Torrance. I wonder. I have my doubts. I and others have come to believe... that your heart is not in this, that you haven't the belly for it.

question: Just give me one more chance to prove it, Mr. Grady. That's all I ask.
answer: Your wife appears to be stronger than we imagined, Mr. Torrance. Somewhat more resourceful, she seems to have got the better of you.

question: For the moment, Mr. Grady. Only for the moment.
answer: I fear that you will have to deal with this matter in the harshest possible way, Mr. Torrance. I fear that is the only thing to do.

question: There's nothing I look forward to with the greater pleasure, Mr. Grady.
answer: You give your word on that do you, Mr. Torrance?

question: Eh...
answer: Wendy, I'm home. Come out, come out, wherever you are!

question: Danny, I can't get out! Run, run and hide. Run, quick!
answer: Little pigs, little pigs, let me come in! Not by the hair on your chiny, chin, chin. Then I'll huff, and I'll puff and I'll blow your house in.

question: Jack. Please. Don't... Don't... Don't! Oh! Please Stop! Jack! Stop it! Stop it! Stop it!
answer: Here's Johnny!

question: Danny! Danny boy! Danny! Danny! Danny!
answer: Danny!

question: Danny! Danny! Danny! Danny! I'm coming. I'm coming Dan!
answer: Danny! Oh!

question: Danny! Danny! I'm coming! You can't get away. I'm right behind you.
answer: Danny!

question: Danny! Danny! Danny! Danny!
answer: Danny! Danny!

question: Danny! Danny!
answer: Mommy...

question: Danny, come here!
answer: Mommy... Mommy...!

question: Danny!
answer: Mommy!
